summary: MAYBE the reason Jon being in love with Dany bothers Sansa is actually the reason she gives: Men in love are easily manipulated....
question: MAYBE the reason Jon being in love with Dany bothers Sansa is actually the reason she gives: Men in love are easily manipulated. She thinks D is taking advantage of Jon, that she tricked him into kneeling. Sansa seemed to be warming up slightly to D until the subject of northern independence came up. I swear, shipping goggles make people see crazy things sometimes.
answer:
She obviously believes that jon is manipulated by dany. Dany’s manipulation and the north’s independence were the main but not the only causes of sansa’s animosity towards dany. Being protective and being jealous are two different things .Sansa’s unwillingness to accept jon’ and dany’s relationship is due to her feelings for jon and l think that the show writers  don’t need to spell it out because sansa’s behavior speaks for itself .

 Sansa is clearly jealous and she doesn’t want to see jon with another woman and dany noticed it, she knows that  sansa doesn’t like the fact that they’re “dating” and that’s why jon is now the primary cause of antagonism between them. They both want him (l said want and not love because l’m starting to believe that dany doesn’t love jon that much she loves  what he represents more than she loves the man  …l’ll stop there because that’s another story) .

Sansa here seemed happy she was looking longingly and smiling at jon ….

and stopped smiling when she noticed that  dany was looking  at jon and  jon was looking and smiling back at her. Even if you don’t ship jonsa you can’t pretend that you didn’t see anything when you saw that scene….nope l won’t believe you that scene had love triangle and jealousy written all over it, she was so happy and then suddenly  her mood swings when she saw jon smilling AT DANY  DANY 

she couldn’t stand seeing them making heart eyes at each other so she left the table abruptly if she could roll her eyes before leaving the table l’m sure she would’ve done it…that’s how irritated she was .

You don’t get upset and leave the room because your brother is smilling at his girlfriend that’s not how a sister is suppoed to react to  that type of scenes.


Also there is that conversation between sansa and tyrion where she asked  why her ?!l

l’m pretty sure that she was talking  to herself because tyrion  can’t give her a satisfying answer since he’s not in jon’s head …she’s been asking herself why her and the only person that can give her that answer is jon she believes that he loves dany and she doesn’t get why !!! she already asked him if he loves dany and now she wants to know why ?! why does he love her ?!


Anyways…. what l really wanted to point out was this dialogue

tyrion” l don’t expect him to spend much time here going forward“

“well l suppose it’s up to him” said sansa on the verge of tears

tyrion: *noticed that she was upset* sansa look at me 

she was so upset that she couldn’t look  at tyrion directly she needed a few seconds to recollect herself.

littlefinger mentioned the fact that sansa wasn’t happy and that there was Something she wanted and did not have and that Something is clearly jon…Dany is trying to take away what sansa wants and she’s clearly not taking it  well.

Aria left and we didn’t see sansa cry over her departure which means that she’s ok with it  so why is the idea of jon going south makes her that sad why is she putting herself through that unnecessary pain if she’s not in love with jon why won’t she let him go?! why can’t she stop talking about their relationship? why can’t she stand  seeing jon with dany?! why is she fighting that hard for him if she’s not in love with him?!!

summary:
Character Choices in GOT 804
For the buildup to the Long Night, the first half of Season 8 featured themes of unity and...
body:
Character Choices in GOT 804

For the buildup to the Long Night, the first half of Season 8 featured themes of unity and togetherness. This episode opens with those same themes as everyone grieves those lost in the battle and then enjoys a rare moment of community to celebrate life at the feast.

However, as Season 8 moves from the Long Night to the fight for the throne, the theme of choice comes roaring back with vengeance.

It starts with Jon’s casual comment about Jorah choosing a way to die.

JON: I didn’t know Ser Jorah well but I know this. If he could have chosen a way to die, it would have been protecting you.

It’s a reminder that Jorah chose Dany first. He was her first protector and the founding member of the Daenerys Targaryen fanclub. Later, he became her first true believer and devoted acolyte. When she walked into fire and emerged unscathed with three dragons, he fell to his knees as her first worshipper. He built the Church of Daenerys, he designed her altar, he maintained her shrine. Every one of her subsequent followers fall in line behind his example.

In 3.05 Kissed By Fire, when Ser Barristan asks if he believes in her, Jorah answers by defining the extent of his devotion: “With my whole heart.” Then Ser Barristan notes that she’ll have to wade through the muck of Westerosi politics if she wants to rule the Seven Kingdoms. In questioning his loyalty, Jorah offers the following direction:

JORAH: If we’re truly her loyal servants, we will do whatever needs to be done, no matter the cost, no matter our pride.

He takes to repeating this again later in 309 and others. The repetition is significant and worth remembering as this episode explores what that phrase may mean in practice.

In 804, Tyrion uses similar Jorah-like language to describe his choice to support Dany. To Sansa, he says “I believe in her.” He expands on that to Varys.

TYRION: At a certain point, you choose a person you believe in, and you fight for that person.

The question Sansa asks is why? Yes, we read her “Why her?” as pure jealousy. But with the dragons flying overhead, it’s also an explicit callback to 3 seasons ago when an exiled Tyrion asked the same question to Jorah in 5.06 Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken.

TYRION: Why Daenerys? Why is she worth all this? As I recall, the Mormonts fought against the Targaryens during Robert’s Rebellion.
JORAH: Do you believe in anything?
TYRION: I believe in lots of things.
JORAH: In something greater than ourselves, I mean. The gods, destiny. Do you believe there’s a plan for this world?
TYRION: No.
JORAH: Neither did I. I was a cynic just like you. Then I saw a girl step into a great fire with three stone eggs. When the fire burned out, I thought I’d find her blackened bones. Instead, I saw her, Daenerys, alive and unhurt, holding her baby dragons. Have you ever heard baby dragons singing?
TYRION: No.
JORAH: It’s hard to be a cynic after that.
TYRION: Doesn’t mean she’s going to be a great queen.
JORAH: No, it doesn’t.
TYRION: The Targaryens are famously insane. What if she conquers the world? Then what? and prosperity?
JORAH: First we have to conquer the world.
TYRION: We? All right, let’s assume your dreams come true. She’s ecstatic when you bring her this enemy dwarf. She hacks off my head and restores your position. You command her army, sail to Westeros, defeat all your enemies and watch her climb those steps and sit on the Iron Throne. Hurrah. Long live the queen. Then what?
JORAH: Then she rules.
TYRION: So a woman who has not spent a single day of her adult life in Westeros becomes the ruler of Westeros? That’s justice?
JORAH: She’s the rightful heir.
TYRION: Why? Because her father, who burned living men for amusement, was the king?

These questions from way back when reverberate into Season 8 and this episode, where Dany shifts to fighting for the throne. Only it’s not Tyrion asking these questions. It’s Sansa.

By this point, Dany recognizes Sansa as her strongest dissenter. Dany wants Jon to stay silent about his new-found identity and swear Sam and Bran to secrecy. When Jon says he has to tell his sisters, Dany zeroes in on Sansa in particular. She objects to telling her because she believes that Sansa will want Dany gone and Jon on the throne. Jon remains resolute as she begs him to stay silent. When Jon doesn’t budge, Dany makes a choice and turns her ask into an order.

JON: We can live together.
DANY: We can. I’ve just told you how.

In the war council, Dany faces two more choices: how and when to attack Cersei. When she expresses a strong preference for a full-strength attack, her advisors present an alternative that would spare the city and she reluctantly agrees.

However, next, Sansa notes the current state of the men Dany has to fight for her, citing exhaustion with many wounded. She suggests taking time for them to recuperate properly and asking the officers for a more detailed timeframe. This is a perfectly reasonable thought. Yet Dany reacts harshly at the mere mention of postponing, responding as if it’s a personal attack. Sansa presses on.

SANSA: It’s not just our people. It’s yours. You want to throw them into a war they’re not ready to fight?
DANY: The longer I leave my enemies alone, the stronger they become. 

And so Dany makes her choice. To march exhausted and wounded men across the country and put them back on a battlefield.

Of note, Jon reacts to Sansa’s fairly reasonable suggestion with a face that silently screams “shutup”, paired with his best “Joffrey is the one true king” impression. He ends echoing a Jorah-like subservience to Dany.

JON: What you command, we will obey.

So, like Tyrion and Jorah, has Jon made his choice? Is Dany the queen he believes in?

No. Jon learned from Jorah what Dany valued and uses it as a mask to placate her. Political!Jon has never been more clearly laid out than in this war council scene, but if you’re still questioning it? Just look at his choice.

Dany asked, begged, and then commanded Jon not to tell Sansa and Arya. But when the Starks stage an intervention, Jon makes his choice to tell them the truth, punctuated by Bran’s words.

BRAN: It’s your choice.

Jon chooses to defy the Dragon Queen.

By making this choice, he directly counters his words to her only a minute earlier.

Thus, confirming once and for all that his Jorah-like subservience is a mummer’s farce.

Before Tyrion leaves, he chooses to talk to Sansa. He’s worried about the relationship with the North and asks why Sansa provokes Dany.

She quickly recognizes what he won’t admit: Tyrion’s afraid of Dany. He tries to justify it as a necessary quality of a ruler, but she sees through it. A beat later, she’s connecting it to Jon, turning to her worry for him going South. She gets more upset when Tyrion notes Jon isn’t a Stark. He tries assuring her with reasons to support his queen.

TYRION: Her people love her, you’ve seen that. You’ve seen how they fight for her. She wants to make the world a better place. I believe in her.

This is a curious couple of lines. Does he mean “her people” are her soldiers? Because only a couple of scenes earlier, Dany was lamenting to Jon about how no one loves her in Westeros. Regardless, none of that answers why she should rule. None of that answers why Tyrion believes in her. 

How did Tyrion change from that cynical questioner in 5.06 to another Jorah-like follower? The moment was so exact, D&D spelled it out for viewers in their comments after the ep: Tyrion watching Dany fly off on a dragon in 5.09 The Dance of Dragons makes him think “she’s the chosen one”.

See, the answer “why her?” was right above Sansa the entire time. It explains Jorah’s support by his own words. It describes the source of Tyrion’s support, by D&D’s own admission. And, most important to Sansa, it explains Jon’s best Jorah impression. As Arya said at the heart tree, they needed her dragons and the armies that came with them to withstand the Long Night. By Dany’s own admission, they were only there because of Jon. And now that the battle is won, Jon is left dealing with the consequences of a plan with no exit strategy.

Except one, which he never planned on. Sansa sees it as the one option available to free Jon from Dany’s grasp and makes a choice.

SANSA: What if there’s someone else? Someone better?

Why does she do this? The answer is simple and she gives it to us earlier.

[Gif source by @tiny-little-bird ]

That’s right. Sansa believes in Jon. What did Tyrion say? “You choose who to believe in and fight for that person?” Well, this is Sansa fighting for Jon. Jon, who is currently so deeply drowning in the depths of an identity crisis, he says goodbye to his friends and gives away Ghost like he’s marching to his death. If ever there was a time Jon needed someone fighting for him, it’s now.

From here, things get interesting. Because Tyrion’s been a hard one to pin down lately. He just got done trying to convince Sansa to support his queen and repeats he believes in her. Yet, once he receives information from Sansa about Jon as another choice, he chooses to tell Varys.

Let’s be clear, Tyrion knows full well Varys’ prior objections to Dany’s choices and his true allegiance to the realm. He tells Varys anyway, thus showing that his belief is not as firm as his words.

Moments later, Team Targ is attacked by the Iron Fleet. Dany loses a dragon, her ships are wrecked, her soldiers are left crawling to shore, and Missandei is in Cersei’s hands.

Dany made the choice to leave when she did. And this is the result.

She responds to these consquences by again wanting to destroy King’s Landing in retaliation. Varys, as promised in 7.02 Stormborn, tells her she’s making a mistake.

VARYS: Do not destroy the city you came to save. Do not become what you have always struggled to defeat.

In response, Dany chooses what she’s willing to sacrifice to win the throne.

DANY: Do you believe we’re here for a reason, Lord Varys? I’m here to free the world from tyrants. That is my destiny and I will serve it, no matter the cost.

Notice those last four words. They match Jorah’s exactly. In an episode that opens on her grieving Jorah’s death, that’s no accident. His death is the fulfillment of these words as he most likely meant them: putting his life on the line for her. However, it sounds much different when Dany says them. She uses them to justify destroying cities, placing the grievous costs on others, to get what she wants: the throne. It tells us that she has no line. She’s willing to do anything and everything.

It also however tragically fulfills Jorah’s true legacy as a maker of a tyrant.

This theme of choices and talk of destiny reminded me of Stannis. Specifically, a conversation in 5.09 The Dance of Dragons (notably also directed by David Nutter).

Shireen is reading a book on The Dance of Dragons and summarizes what its about to Stannis. He poses a question.

STANNIS: If you had to choose between Rhaenyra and Aegon who would you have chosen?
SHIREEN: I wouldn’t have chosen either. It’s all the choosing sides that made everything so horrible.
STANNIS: Sometimes a person has to choose. Sometimes the world forces his hand. If a man knows what he is and remains true to himself the choice is no choice at all. He must fulfill his destiny and become who he is meant to be. However much he may hate it.

Stannis thought his destiny required him to burn his daughter at the stake to win a crown. He was wrong.

In Dany’s choice to take the throne, no matter the cost, she’ll be wrong too.

The question is who will stand by her. And who will stop her.

VARYS: Each of us has a choice to make. I pray we choose wisely.

The question Sansa asks is why? Yes, we read her “Why her?” as pure jealousy. But with the dragons flying overhead, it’s also an explicit callback to 3 seasons ago when an exiled Tyrion asked the same question to Jorah in 5.06 Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken.

TYRION: Why Daenerys? Why is she worth all this? As I recall, the Mormonts fought against the Targaryens during Robert’s Rebellion.
JORAH: Do you believe in anything?
TYRION: I believe in lots of things.
JORAH: In something greater than ourselves, I mean. The gods, destiny. Do you believe there’s a plan for this world?
TYRION: No.
JORAH: Neither did I. I was a cynic just like you. Then I saw a girl step into a great fire with three stone eggs. When the fire burned out, I thought I’d find her blackened bones. Instead, I saw her, Daenerys, alive and unhurt, holding her baby dragons. Have you ever heard baby dragons singing?
TYRION: No.
JORAH: It’s hard to be a cynic after that.
TYRION: Doesn’t mean she’s going to be a great queen.
JORAH: No, it doesn’t.
TYRION: The Targaryens are famously insane. What if she conquers the world? Then what? and prosperity?
JORAH: First we have to conquer the world.
TYRION: We? All right, let’s assume your dreams come true. She’s ecstatic when you bring her this enemy dwarf. She hacks off my head and restores your position. You command her army, sail to Westeros, defeat all your enemies and watch her climb those steps and sit on the Iron Throne. Hurrah. Long live the queen. Then what?
JORAH: Then she rules.
TYRION: So a woman who has not spent a single day of her adult life in Westeros becomes the ruler of Westeros? That’s justice?
JORAH: She’s the rightful heir.
TYRION: Why? Because her father, who burned living men for amusement, was the king?

These questions from way back when reverberate into Season 8 and this episode, where Dany shifts to fighting for the throne. Only it’s not Tyrion asking these questions. It’s Sansa.

By this point, Dany recognizes Sansa as her strongest dissenter. Dany wants Jon to stay silent about his new-found identity and swear Sam and Bran to secrecy. When Jon says he has to tell his sisters, Dany zeroes in on Sansa in particular. She objects to telling her because she believes that Sansa will want Dany gone and Jon on the throne. Jon remains resolute as she begs him to stay silent. When Jon doesn’t budge, Dany makes a choice and turns her ask into an order.

JON: We can live together.
DANY: We can. I’ve just told you how.

In the war council, Dany faces two more choices: how and when to attack Cersei. When she expresses a strong preference for a full-strength attack, her advisors present an alternative that would spare the city and she reluctantly agrees.

However, next, Sansa notes the current state of the men Dany has to fight for her, citing exhaustion with many wounded. She suggests taking time for them to recuperate properly and asking the officers for a more detailed timeframe. This is a perfectly reasonable thought. Yet Dany reacts harshly at the mere mention of postponing, responding as if it’s a personal attack. Sansa presses on.

SANSA: It’s not just our people. It’s yours. You want to throw them into a war they’re not ready to fight?
DANY: The longer I leave my enemies alone, the stronger they become. 

And so Dany makes her choice. To march exhausted and wounded men across the country and put them back on a battlefield.

Of note, Jon reacts to Sansa’s fairly reasonable suggestion with a face that silently screams “shutup”, paired with his best “Joffrey is the one true king” impression. He ends echoing a Jorah-like subservience to Dany.

JON: What you command, we will obey.

So, like Tyrion and Jorah, has Jon made his choice? Is Dany the queen he believes in?

No. Jon learned from Jorah what Dany valued and uses it as a mask to placate her. Political!Jon has never been more clearly laid out than in this war council scene, but if you’re still questioning it? Just look at his choice.

Dany asked, begged, and then commanded Jon not to tell Sansa and Arya. But when the Starks stage an intervention, Jon makes his choice to tell them the truth, punctuated by Bran’s words.

BRAN: It’s your choice.

Jon chooses to defy the Dragon Queen.

By making this choice, he directly counters his words to her only a minute earlier.

Thus, confirming once and for all that his Jorah-like subservience is a mummer’s farce.

Before Tyrion leaves, he chooses to talk to Sansa. He’s worried about the relationship with the North and asks why Sansa provokes Dany.

She quickly recognizes what he won’t admit: Tyrion’s afraid of Dany. He tries to justify it as a necessary quality of a ruler, but she sees through it. A beat later, she’s connecting it to Jon, turning to her worry for him going South. She gets more upset when Tyrion notes Jon isn’t a Stark. He tries assuring her with reasons to support his queen.

TYRION: Her people love her, you’ve seen that. You’ve seen how they fight for her. She wants to make the world a better place. I believe in her.

This is a curious couple of lines. Does he mean “her people” are her soldiers? Because only a couple of scenes earlier, Dany was lamenting to Jon about how no one loves her in Westeros. Regardless, none of that answers why she should rule. None of that answers why Tyrion believes in her. 

How did Tyrion change from that cynical questioner in 5.06 to another Jorah-like follower? The moment was so exact, D&D spelled it out for viewers in their comments after the ep: Tyrion watching Dany fly off on a dragon in 5.09 The Dance of Dragons makes him think “she’s the chosen one”.

See, the answer “why her?” was right above Sansa the entire time. It explains Jorah’s support by his own words. It describes the source of Tyrion’s support, by D&D’s own admission. And, most important to Sansa, it explains Jon’s best Jorah impression. As Arya said at the heart tree, they needed her dragons and the armies that came with them to withstand the Long Night. By Dany’s own admission, they were only there because of Jon. And now that the battle is won, Jon is left dealing with the consequences of a plan with no exit strategy.

Except one, which he never planned on. Sansa sees it as the one option available to free Jon from Dany’s grasp and makes a choice.

SANSA: What if there’s someone else? Someone better?

Why does she do this? The answer is simple and she gives it to us earlier.

[Gif source by @tiny-little-bird ]

That’s right. Sansa believes in Jon. What did Tyrion say? “You choose who to believe in and fight for that person?” Well, this is Sansa fighting for Jon. Jon, who is currently so deeply drowning in the depths of an identity crisis, he says goodbye to his friends and gives away Ghost like he’s marching to his death. If ever there was a time Jon needed someone fighting for him, it’s now.

From here, things get interesting. Because Tyrion’s been a hard one to pin down lately. He just got done trying to convince Sansa to support his queen and repeats he believes in her. Yet, once he receives information from Sansa about Jon as another choice, he chooses to tell Varys.

Let’s be clear, Tyrion knows full well Varys’ prior objections to Dany’s choices and his true allegiance to the realm. He tells Varys anyway, thus showing that his belief is not as firm as his words.

Moments later, Team Targ is attacked by the Iron Fleet. Dany loses a dragon, her ships are wrecked, her soldiers are left crawling to shore, and Missandei is in Cersei’s hands.

Dany made the choice to leave when she did. And this is the result.

She responds to these consquences by again wanting to destroy King’s Landing in retaliation. Varys, as promised in 7.02 Stormborn, tells her she’s making a mistake.

VARYS: Do not destroy the city you came to save. Do not become what you have always struggled to defeat.

In response, Dany chooses what she’s willing to sacrifice to win the throne.

DANY: Do you believe we’re here for a reason, Lord Varys? I’m here to free the world from tyrants. That is my destiny and I will serve it, no matter the cost.

Notice those last four words. They match Jorah’s exactly. In an episode that opens on her grieving Jorah’s death, that’s no accident. His death is the fulfillment of these words as he most likely meant them: putting his life on the line for her. However, it sounds much different when Dany says them. She uses them to justify destroying cities, placing the grievous costs on others, to get what she wants: the throne. It tells us that she has no line. She’s willing to do anything and everything.

It also however tragically fulfills Jorah’s true legacy as a maker of a tyrant.

This theme of choices and talk of destiny reminded me of Stannis. Specifically, a conversation in 5.09 The Dance of Dragons (notably also directed by David Nutter).

Shireen is reading a book on The Dance of Dragons and summarizes what its about to Stannis. He poses a question.

STANNIS: If you had to choose between Rhaenyra and Aegon who would you have chosen?
SHIREEN: I wouldn’t have chosen either. It’s all the choosing sides that made everything so horrible.
STANNIS: Sometimes a person has to choose. Sometimes the world forces his hand. If a man knows what he is and remains true to himself the choice is no choice at all. He must fulfill his destiny and become who he is meant to be. However much he may hate it.

Stannis thought his destiny required him to burn his daughter at the stake to win a crown. He was wrong.

In Dany’s choice to take the throne, no matter the cost, she’ll be wrong too.

The question is who will stand by her. And who will stop her.

VARYS: Each of us has a choice to make. I pray we choose wisely.

Let’s be clear, Tyrion knows full well Varys’ prior objections to Dany’s choices and his true allegiance to the realm. He tells Varys anyway, thus showing that his belief is not as firm as his words.

Moments later, Team Targ is attacked by the Iron Fleet. Dany loses a dragon, her ships are wrecked, her soldiers are left crawling to shore, and Missandei is in Cersei’s hands.

Dany made the choice to leave when she did. And this is the result.

She responds to these consquences by again wanting to destroy King’s Landing in retaliation. Varys, as promised in 7.02 Stormborn, tells her she’s making a mistake.

VARYS: Do not destroy the city you came to save. Do not become what you have always struggled to defeat.

In response, Dany chooses what she’s willing to sacrifice to win the throne.

DANY: Do you believe we’re here for a reason, Lord Varys? I’m here to free the world from tyrants. That is my destiny and I will serve it, no matter the cost.

Notice those last four words. They match Jorah’s exactly. In an episode that opens on her grieving Jorah’s death, that’s no accident. His death is the fulfillment of these words as he most likely meant them: putting his life on the line for her. However, it sounds much different when Dany says them. She uses them to justify destroying cities, placing the grievous costs on others, to get what she wants: the throne. It tells us that she has no line. She’s willing to do anything and everything.

It also however tragically fulfills Jorah’s true legacy as a maker of a tyrant.

This theme of choices and talk of destiny reminded me of Stannis. Specifically, a conversation in 5.09 The Dance of Dragons (notably also directed by David Nutter).

Shireen is reading a book on The Dance of Dragons and summarizes what its about to Stannis. He poses a question.

STANNIS: If you had to choose between Rhaenyra and Aegon who would you have chosen?
SHIREEN: I wouldn’t have chosen either. It’s all the choosing sides that made everything so horrible.
STANNIS: Sometimes a person has to choose. Sometimes the world forces his hand. If a man knows what he is and remains true to himself the choice is no choice at all. He must fulfill his destiny and become who he is meant to be. However much he may hate it.

Stannis thought his destiny required him to burn his daughter at the stake to win a crown. He was wrong.

In Dany’s choice to take the throne, no matter the cost, she’ll be wrong too.

The question is who will stand by her. And who will stop her.

VARYS: Each of us has a choice to make. I pray we choose wisely.

summary: 8x04 Literary Symmetry;  how Jon and Sansa paralleled Ned and Catelyn
body:
8x04 Literary Symmetry; how Jon and Sansa paralleled Ned and Catelyn

(Apologies if there are formatting issues; I’m on mobile)

But I just got done typing up a response to @wintersqueen regarding the shut out Stark POV for the RLJ reveal& I just had a realization….

We opened s8 with the knowledge that the season premiere was meant to mirror the pilot, but, frankly, all of s8 has been one parallel after the other. Dan comes in, and is meant to be a stand in for Robert—the arriving king queen. But we see the post-battle feast at the beginning of the episode, which mirrors the feast from the premiere.

Except now, instead of Jon being the bastard of the back of the room, Arya is the one that feels like an outsider. Jon, instead, is at the high table between Sansa and Dany. Instead of affection between everyone, there is tension—much like there was tension between Ned, Robert, and (consequently) Catelyn following Robert asking demanding Ned to come south to be his hand. (This conversation also happened in the crypts, where Jon told Dan about RLJ) Catelyn diesn’t want Ned to go (Sansa doesn’t want Jon to go), but she knows that he is honor hound to his king (Jon’s made it clear that they’re going to follow Dan). Not only that, but Ned and Robert are good friends, there’s love there (Sansa believes they are in love). In the bedroom scene, Catelyn recieves the letter from Lysa in which they now learn that the Lannisters supposedly killed Jon Arryn. So now she understands that Ned is in danger. (I think this parallels the Godswood conversation that we were shut out of—i didn’t bring this up in my last post, but what if Jon told them that if he didn’t march south, and if they didn’t keep this secret, that Dan would hurt them? This would explain why Sansa was so panicked following the reveal, and why she didn’t want to tell Tyrion, but once she realized that Dan’s own “loyal advisors” were scared of her, too, that she had to do something.)

But, Just like Catelyn, Sansa must stay in Winterfell. Sansa’s not a battle commander, so going to Kl is pointless for her. And she’s the Lady of Winterfell, so she needs to be in Winterfell. Because there must always be a Stark in Winterfell, right? She’s the Lady of Winterfell, right?

But this isn’t enough. Just like the forces for BoB weren’t enough, simply telling Tyrion about Jon’s heritage isn’t enough. Can she trust Tyrion with the fate of her family? With Jon? Just like Catelyn trusting a raven to carry the message about the Lannisters sending the assassin for Bran, she has to do this herself.

So, I predict that Sansa is going to leave Winterfell, just like Catelyn did. And she’s going to leave Bran as the Lord of Winterfell, just as he was when Robb ended up leaving (Why else have the conversation between Tyrion and Bran, reminding us that he’s the lord?)

She was wearing her Tully dress in that episode, the one Michelle designed to represent that side of her heritage. Maybe she’ll go to the Riverlands to procure more forces for Jon? (I think someone else speculated this, already? I’m not sure.) Except she’s going to go in person, this time, since Brienne wasn’t successful going as an envoy (everyone’s skeptical, and who can blame them?).

I’m sure Brienne wants to go south, too, because that’s where Jaime’s going—and, let’s face it, no matter how much Brienne loves Jaime, she won’t break her oath to Sansa(Gwen even said so herself). So instead of Sansa giving Brienne permission to go, Sansa will bring Brienne with her, just like Catelyn brought Ser Rodrick.

Sophie described her as “The Warrior of Winterfell,” and I think we’re going to see exactly that. Just like Catelyn marched with Robb, now Sansa will campaign.

.

On a scale of Aerys to Sansa, how crazy am I?

summary: It would be cool if ep 5 includes a scene in which the Lady of Winterfell invites the new Lord of Storm's End to have supper...
body:
It would be cool if ep 5 includes a scene in which the Lady of Winterfell invites the new Lord of Storm’s End to have supper with her to discuss alliances. But when Gendry arrives (all flustered because he’s not in his element), it is just a normal dinner in which she asked him why he did such stupid thing as aks Arya to marry him, when he should have proposed her to go and travel the damn world together.

Also, it would have been a hell of a parallel with the scene in which Arya reunites with Jon.

Since the beginning, the two sisters didn’t get along because Arya always thought Sansa was a stupid girl who lived in a fantasy world with little to no aspirations; and Sansa made fun of Arya for being reluctant to accept society norms and act like a boy instead of the little lady she was, and insist on the fact nobody will like her. Ever.

But now, after all this time and everything they’ve been through, Arya recognizes Sansa as the most clever person in the world, as she says it to Jon, and also a very good and irreplaceable leader.

So I think it would be nice to have Sansa acknowledging Arya as the hero she is, but also an adventurer that deserves all the love in the world, but in her own terms.

blog.name: ruta-yawara
blog.title: There are worlds where the sky is burning

summary:
The more it takes away (I of II)
(I wanted to finish it before tomorrow's episode. Inspired by old leaks about a possible...
body:
The more it takes away (I of II)

(I wanted to finish it before tomorrow’s episode. Inspired by old leaks about a possible Sansa’s abduction. This the first part of two.)

*

It’s a sunny day despite the freezing air. It isn’t snowing. The breath condenses in front of him, a sign that despite everything, he is continuing to breathe. He feels his lungs on fire, as if he’s underwater.

The walls are high and thick, with wooden posts built upon the battlements, on which tens of scorpion bolts are placed.

Cersei Lannister is on one of these. She has a smile that drives him to leave the ranks of soldiers and advance towards the closed doors of the city under siege.

It spreads fear and threat of terror. A chilling dread.

His worst fear materializes in the glimpse of red hair behind her. He wants to scream. Instead he remains paralyzed with horror, the only noise being the pulsing buzz of blood in his ears. It’s like Rickon, only a thousand times more devastating.

Jon watches her approaching Sansa, slow and predatory, sharp and calculating. He watches how Cersei caresses her cheek with her nails, then grabs her chin and whispers something into her ear.

Sansa’s face remains expressionless, but her eyes tell another story, betray what she really feels. Gods.

Sansa takes a step forward and from the way she moves no one would guess she is about to die. She will not beg nor she will run away. She has no chains or handcuffs.

Her eyes are incredibly blue, her hair a flaming mass. When she speaks, her voice sounds stentorian across the clearing.

“I will die like my father. I have no regrets except one.” Her gaze finds his, liquid and sad and fierce at the same time. A ferrous taste invades his mouth. He has bitten his lip. “The north remembers.”

The sword swings, the head falls, the body with it. The last spark caught by the sun of copper hair, streams of warm blood, the terrible sound of the thud.

He screams at the top of his lungs. And through him so the direwolf and the dragon and -

He sits up with a start. He’s in his tent. It’s still night. He rubs a hand over his face. He is soaked in cold sweat.

It was just a dream. A nightmare.

Sansa is safe, in Winterfell. He made sure for it to happen.

He closes his eyes and shreds of images run through his mind. No matter how hard he tries, he can’t delete them from memory. Deep roots like those of a heart tree are wedged inside him.

After that night, it becomes a recurring dream. See her die, night after night, again and again.

Despite his attempts, every time something inside him seems to break and the craving for home becomes agonizing.

*

“They had to be full of water and instead were empty! How is that possible?”

Of all those present, no one speaks. Tyrion stirs by the queen’s side and Varys remains inscrutable. Davos exchanges a look with Gendry and takes a step forward.

“With all due respect, my lord, Gendry and I were in charge of filling them,” he says. “We can both confirm that they were full when we delivered them to Gray Worm.”

Jon closes his eyes. His hands are locked around the table on which the map of King’s Landing is deployed. His knuckles turn white. When he stares at Gray Worm, he in his usual position, next to Daenerys, with his arms crossed behind his back.

“You ordered them to be emptied,” he accuses him, but his voice sounds more tired than really angry. “Why?”

Gray Worm doesn’t so much as look at him. When he speaks, he turns and looks at the queen, as if the presence and opinion of others are of no relevance to him. “That woman is like the Masters and we will treat her the same way.”

Daenerys doesn’t respond, but her face shows the same hardness that she hasn’t lost since Missandei’s death. She puts her hand on his elbow.

Jon thinks about Mance Rayder. Burnt alive is something he wouldn’t wish to anyone, not even to his worst enemy.

The plan was to burn a small portion of the Flea Bottom, a displaced area and according to reliable sources now uninhabited, and at the same time to launch with catapults barrels of water to extinguish the flames. A play to show the devastating power of a dragon, the threat behind the warning, and have mercy, give a clear message that they are not the true enemy, but that they could become one.

To do something, quieting the desire for bloodbath of the Unsellied.

“What about the women and children who could have died?”

Gray Worm doesn’t blink. “There are always casualties in war.” Everyone knows that he is referring to Missandei.

Out of the corner of his eye he sees Tyrion flinch under Daenerys’ glare.

“You knew it?” He brutally asks her.

Daenerys’s eyes catalyses on him, losing some of her coolness. She hesitates, as if evaluating the options. “No,” she says.

Jon nods, trying to mask the relief he is feeling.

“So it’s insubordination,” he says gravely. From the way she is staring at him, Jon senses that she has already figured out what this means.

“I respected you as commander, but what you did today was unforgivable. We can’t fight a war if we don’t trust each other.”

When they are alone, Daenerys’ fury is incandescent. “What do you think you’re doing?” There is a ferocity in her eyes, the look of a bear mother to which were killed all her cubs, one after the other. “Gray Worm is my commander, a trusted man of the queen.”

“He disobeyed an order! What example would we give to the other commanders if he remains unpunished?”

“I will not punish him just because he sought justice.”

“That wasn’t justice! It was revenge! If we start acting this way, what makes us better than Cersei Lannister?”

He knows he has convinced her when he sees her shrink under the weight of that umpteenth loss.

He would like to comfort her, but as a coward he turns his back and leaves.

*

“My queen, we were willing to follow you and serve you to the ends of the world.” Gray Worm is kneeling in front of Daenerys, like a loyal, faithful subject. “We did it. I can reach her now. Will you bury us in Naath?”

The queen’s eyes are shiny and she is pale as the moon while she nods and promises to fulfill his last wish.

After Gray Worm dies, Daenerys remains, staring at his lifeless body.

When Jon approaches, she turns around. Her braids are ruffled by the wind and the hardness has reached her eyes. He immediately realizes that he has lost her fully.

“You can’t force a dragon to behave like a sheep,” she murmurs and her fury is blinding, mixed with grief. “At dawn I will set the city on fire.”

*

Jon enters the queen’s tent last. It seems to him that only a few moments have passed since Gray Worm’s execution. He tried to talk to Daenerys, but she took off with Drogon. He spent the last few hours among the ranks of soldiers, organizing water supplies with Davos.

When he enters, silence falls like a sword. Every gaze is fixed on him, every word truncated while it was spoken, each head turns and between them stands out one of a bright red.

Jon blinks and thinks it’s a hallucination, an illusion due to the lack of light in the tent lit by candles. But the head remains red and the face is just that of -

“Tormund? Why are you here? I thought-” That we would never see each other again.

Tormund embraces him, a proud and bone-breaking hug. When he lets go, giving him one last pat on the shoulder, Jon notices his grim expression. The smile dies on his lips.

“I couldn’t let anyone else tell you.” His hand remains firm on his shoulder. Something cold and slimy grabs him by the scruff. “We were one day walking towards the North when your beast reached me. He was covered in blood. I went back immediately, but it was too late.”

His mind is a whirlwind of alternatives. Winterfell burned to the ground. Sansa, Arya and Bran killed -

“They took her, boy. Those fucking bastards took your sister.”

“Which of the two?” Someone asks.

He and Tormund snap their heads to their right.

Tyrion raises his hands, as conciliator as usual. “It’s a legitimate question,” he defends himself. “Jon has two sisters, Lady Sansa and Lady Arya.”

“Sansa,” Tormund replies in a grunt. His grumpy voice seems to come from far away. “She’s the one they took.”

Sansa. They took Sansa.

“Why? What do they hope to achieve?” asks Davos.

“An interesting question mainly because it provides multiple answers,” intervenes Varys. “They could use her as a hostage. Or simply exploit her name. Let’s not forget that she remains the key to the North.”

Sansa has been kidnapped. At this very moment she could be at the mercy of Cersei Lannister. Suddenly his stomach is twisted and his vision blurred.

“Jon-” begins Davos.

“He is a bastard,” Varys interrupts him without half measures, “and unless the queen doesn’t legitimize him as she did with the bastard of Robert Baratheon, the only legitimate heir that can continue the lineage are her and Lady Arya.”

Jon forces himself not to think about Sansa, the thousand ways she could be tortured. Her wounded and swollen skin, her piercing screams of pain.

There is a sudden silence, full of tension. He has recently started breathing again normally when he meets Daenerys’ gaze. It contain pity, but also something that he cannot define, as if a light illuminates it from within. “Family names are handed down from father to son,” Daenerys states. “We’re not in Dorne.”

“Not necessarily,” Varys contradicts. Daenerys finally looks away from him. “There have been cases, your grace, when no male heirs were available. Also in your family.”

“So what’s the plan?” Davos questions. “Obviously we cannot proceed as originally agreed, not now that we know that Lady Sansa is within the city.”

He is obviously referring to the old plan, the one that provided for localized fires, for closing the access to the sea. To win the war by exhaustion.

Most of the men are waiting for his word, but he looks at Daenerys, at her lips curved downwards. He’s shivering inside.

“I don’t intend to change our strategy.”

For a moment he is sure he has misunderstood. He must have hear wrong. He realizes this isn’t the case from Davos’ obvious discomfort, Gendry’s disbelief, Tormund’s confusion and the exchange of glances between Tyrion and Varys.

“What are you talking about?” His voice sounds hoarse and harsh. It’s the first time he speaks. Anger blooms in his chest like a flower of fire. Makes him almost feverish. He feels less powerless. “If Sansa is in there, is all the more reason not to set the whole city on fire.”

Daenerys’s face doesn’t change expression. “I’m sorry for your loss, but your sister is brave. I’m sure -”

He won’t let her finish. He doesn’t want to hear. “Out.” He doesn’t scream, but the tone he used doesn’t leave other possible interpretations. It is a mandatory, imperative order. “All of you. Leave us alone.”

They do as he said and passing by Tyrion stops near him. He seems to want to tell him something, but in the end he closes his mouth and shakes the head.

Left alone, he turns to her, blinded by a black fury. “If you think I’ll let you kill my sister-”

“She’s not your sister.”

“She’s my family,” he growls.

She raises her chin and there is a quiet determination in her, a plea and a need, something that shakes him deeply when she says, “I’m your family too.”

“So did we get to this point? Do you force me to choose between Sansa’s life and you?”

Daenerys approaches and when she rests her hands on the sides of his face, he feels the strangest of sensations. They are familiar hands, whose touch he should recognize. It isn’t so. “I ask you to choose between the future and the past.”

He feels drained, as if he had been deprived of something. He doesn’t even know what it is. Only that it is of fundamental importance. “You’re wrong. You can’t choose between the two. There’s no future without a past.”

“So you’re choosing her.”

He grabs her wrists and sighs, before gently turning away from her. “There are other ways to take the city. Safer ways.”

“Slower,” she replies, frowning.

Jon can’t tell her it’s not true. “Righteous.”

He has one foot out of the tent when her voice reaches him. “Do you think she will be treated with respect? All say the opposite. Even if you could save her, think of the state in which you will find her.”

He squints his eyes painfully. After a moment he leaves.

*

“We can save her, little crow. Your sister is Ladyluck after all.”

He looks optimistic, but it’s a farce.

LadyLuck. He doesn’t remember the moment when Tormund started calling Sansa that way. He would like to remember.

Kissed by fire, he thinks. But that didn’t save Ygritte.

“If you’re going to throw up, just do it now.”

Jon keeps staring at the fire. “Everything I did, I did it for them,” he mutters. For her. “I said goodbye to my home, to my family to protect them and now-” now she will never know why he did it. She will always think that he has turned his back to the North, to her.

“How could this happen?” Where was everybody when it happened?

Here they are again. Disappointment, frustration, disgust, outrage. He wants to smash everything to smithereens. He clenches his jaw and throw a log of wood into the fire. There is a high flame before the wood begins to crackle and burn.

“The she-wolf was gone a day after you. I thought I would find her here. The giant woman has disappeared so they must have taken her too.”

Therefore Sansa isn’t alone.

There is still something that is consuming a corner of his mind. “Tormund. You said that Ghost reached you. Wasn’t he with you?”

He scratches at his beard. “He never left the castle.”

“Why?”

“She has a way with words.” Tormund shrugs and grins smugly. “All she had to do was to shed a few tears from her pretty blue eyes for the damn beast to run into her open arms.”

Jon frowns. Why Sansa should care-

Tormund knows him well enough to understand what he is thinking. “Are you fucking kidding? The girl loves your beast. When you were stuck in the South they were butt buddies. Didn’t you know?”

Something seems to compress in his chest. “I asked him to protect her in my place. I had forgotten.”

“You forgot enough, didn’t you? Do you remember who you are?”

Yes, he thinks and it has never been more true.

“My queen, we were willing to follow you and serve you to the ends of the world.” Gray Worm is kneeling in front of Daenerys, like a loyal, faithful subject. “We did it. I can reach her now. Will you bury us in Naath?”

The queen’s eyes are shiny and she is pale as the moon while she nods and promises to fulfill his last wish.

After Gray Worm dies, Daenerys remains, staring at his lifeless body.

When Jon approaches, she turns around. Her braids are ruffled by the wind and the hardness has reached her eyes. He immediately realizes that he has lost her fully.

“You can’t force a dragon to behave like a sheep,” she murmurs and her fury is blinding, mixed with grief. “At dawn I will set the city on fire.”

*

Jon enters the queen’s tent last. It seems to him that only a few moments have passed since Gray Worm’s execution. He tried to talk to Daenerys, but she took off with Drogon. He spent the last few hours among the ranks of soldiers, organizing water supplies with Davos.

When he enters, silence falls like a sword. Every gaze is fixed on him, every word truncated while it was spoken, each head turns and between them stands out one of a bright red.

Jon blinks and thinks it’s a hallucination, an illusion due to the lack of light in the tent lit by candles. But the head remains red and the face is just that of -

“Tormund? Why are you here? I thought-” That we would never see each other again.

Tormund embraces him, a proud and bone-breaking hug. When he lets go, giving him one last pat on the shoulder, Jon notices his grim expression. The smile dies on his lips.

“I couldn’t let anyone else tell you.” His hand remains firm on his shoulder. Something cold and slimy grabs him by the scruff. “We were one day walking towards the North when your beast reached me. He was covered in blood. I went back immediately, but it was too late.”

His mind is a whirlwind of alternatives. Winterfell burned to the ground. Sansa, Arya and Bran killed -

“They took her, boy. Those fucking bastards took your sister.”

“Which of the two?” Someone asks.

He and Tormund snap their heads to their right.

Tyrion raises his hands, as conciliator as usual. “It’s a legitimate question,” he defends himself. “Jon has two sisters, Lady Sansa and Lady Arya.”

“Sansa,” Tormund replies in a grunt. His grumpy voice seems to come from far away. “She’s the one they took.”

Sansa. They took Sansa.

“Why? What do they hope to achieve?” asks Davos.

“An interesting question mainly because it provides multiple answers,” intervenes Varys. “They could use her as a hostage. Or simply exploit her name. Let’s not forget that she remains the key to the North.”

Sansa has been kidnapped. At this very moment she could be at the mercy of Cersei Lannister. Suddenly his stomach is twisted and his vision blurred.

“Jon-” begins Davos.

“He is a bastard,” Varys interrupts him without half measures, “and unless the queen doesn’t legitimize him as she did with the bastard of Robert Baratheon, the only legitimate heir that can continue the lineage are her and Lady Arya.”

Jon forces himself not to think about Sansa, the thousand ways she could be tortured. Her wounded and swollen skin, her piercing screams of pain.

There is a sudden silence, full of tension. He has recently started breathing again normally when he meets Daenerys’ gaze. It contain pity, but also something that he cannot define, as if a light illuminates it from within. “Family names are handed down from father to son,” Daenerys states. “We’re not in Dorne.”

“Not necessarily,” Varys contradicts. Daenerys finally looks away from him. “There have been cases, your grace, when no male heirs were available. Also in your family.”

“So what’s the plan?” Davos questions. “Obviously we cannot proceed as originally agreed, not now that we know that Lady Sansa is within the city.”

He is obviously referring to the old plan, the one that provided for localized fires, for closing the access to the sea. To win the war by exhaustion.

Most of the men are waiting for his word, but he looks at Daenerys, at her lips curved downwards. He’s shivering inside.

“I don’t intend to change our strategy.”

For a moment he is sure he has misunderstood. He must have hear wrong. He realizes this isn’t the case from Davos’ obvious discomfort, Gendry’s disbelief, Tormund’s confusion and the exchange of glances between Tyrion and Varys.

“What are you talking about?” His voice sounds hoarse and harsh. It’s the first time he speaks. Anger blooms in his chest like a flower of fire. Makes him almost feverish. He feels less powerless. “If Sansa is in there, is all the more reason not to set the whole city on fire.”

Daenerys’s face doesn’t change expression. “I’m sorry for your loss, but your sister is brave. I’m sure -”

He won’t let her finish. He doesn’t want to hear. “Out.” He doesn’t scream, but the tone he used doesn’t leave other possible interpretations. It is a mandatory, imperative order. “All of you. Leave us alone.”

They do as he said and passing by Tyrion stops near him. He seems to want to tell him something, but in the end he closes his mouth and shakes the head.

Left alone, he turns to her, blinded by a black fury. “If you think I’ll let you kill my sister-”

“She’s not your sister.”

“She’s my family,” he growls.

She raises her chin and there is a quiet determination in her, a plea and a need, something that shakes him deeply when she says, “I’m your family too.”

“So did we get to this point? Do you force me to choose between Sansa’s life and you?”

Daenerys approaches and when she rests her hands on the sides of his face, he feels the strangest of sensations. They are familiar hands, whose touch he should recognize. It isn’t so. “I ask you to choose between the future and the past.”

He feels drained, as if he had been deprived of something. He doesn’t even know what it is. Only that it is of fundamental importance. “You’re wrong. You can’t choose between the two. There’s no future without a past.”

“So you’re choosing her.”

He grabs her wrists and sighs, before gently turning away from her. “There are other ways to take the city. Safer ways.”

“Slower,” she replies, frowning.

Jon can’t tell her it’s not true. “Righteous.”

He has one foot out of the tent when her voice reaches him. “Do you think she will be treated with respect? All say the opposite. Even if you could save her, think of the state in which you will find her.”

He squints his eyes painfully. After a moment he leaves.

*

“We can save her, little crow. Your sister is Ladyluck after all.”

He looks optimistic, but it’s a farce.

LadyLuck. He doesn’t remember the moment when Tormund started calling Sansa that way. He would like to remember.

Kissed by fire, he thinks. But that didn’t save Ygritte.

“If you’re going to throw up, just do it now.”

Jon keeps staring at the fire. “Everything I did, I did it for them,” he mutters. For her. “I said goodbye to my home, to my family to protect them and now-” now she will never know why he did it. She will always think that he has turned his back to the North, to her.

“How could this happen?” Where was everybody when it happened?

Here they are again. Disappointment, frustration, disgust, outrage. He wants to smash everything to smithereens. He clenches his jaw and throw a log of wood into the fire. There is a high flame before the wood begins to crackle and burn.

“The she-wolf was gone a day after you. I thought I would find her here. The giant woman has disappeared so they must have taken her too.”

Therefore Sansa isn’t alone.

There is still something that is consuming a corner of his mind. “Tormund. You said that Ghost reached you. Wasn’t he with you?”

He scratches at his beard. “He never left the castle.”

“Why?”

“She has a way with words.” Tormund shrugs and grins smugly. “All she had to do was to shed a few tears from her pretty blue eyes for the damn beast to run into her open arms.”

Jon frowns. Why Sansa should care-

Tormund knows him well enough to understand what he is thinking. “Are you fucking kidding? The girl loves your beast. When you were stuck in the South they were butt buddies. Didn’t you know?”

Something seems to compress in his chest. “I asked him to protect her in my place. I had forgotten.”

“You forgot enough, didn’t you? Do you remember who you are?”

Yes, he thinks and it has never been more true.
trail.content:
The more it takes away (I of II)

(I wanted to finish it before tomorrow’s episode. Inspired by old leaks about a possible Sansa’s abduction. This the first part of two.)

*

It’s a sunny day despite the freezing air. It isn’t snowing. The breath condenses in front of him, a sign that despite everything, he is continuing to breathe. He feels his lungs on fire, as if he’s underwater.

The walls are high and thick, with wooden posts built upon the battlements, on which tens of scorpion bolts are placed.

Cersei Lannister is on one of these. She has a smile that drives him to leave the ranks of soldiers and advance towards the closed doors of the city under siege.

It spreads fear and threat of terror. A chilling dread.

His worst fear materializes in the glimpse of red hair behind her. He wants to scream. Instead he remains paralyzed with horror, the only noise being the pulsing buzz of blood in his ears. It’s like Rickon, only a thousand times more devastating.

Jon watches her approaching Sansa, slow and predatory, sharp and calculating. He watches how Cersei caresses her cheek with her nails, then grabs her chin and whispers something into her ear.

Sansa’s face remains expressionless, but her eyes tell another story, betray what she really feels. Gods.

Sansa takes a step forward and from the way she moves no one would guess she is about to die. She will not beg nor she will run away. She has no chains or handcuffs.

Her eyes are incredibly blue, her hair a flaming mass. When she speaks, her voice sounds stentorian across the clearing.

“I will die like my father. I have no regrets except one.” Her gaze finds his, liquid and sad and fierce at the same time. A ferrous taste invades his mouth. He has bitten his lip. “The north remembers.”

The sword swings, the head falls, the body with it. The last spark caught by the sun of copper hair, streams of warm blood, the terrible sound of the thud.

He screams at the top of his lungs. And through him so the direwolf and the dragon and -

He sits up with a start. He’s in his tent. It’s still night. He rubs a hand over his face. He is soaked in cold sweat.

It was just a dream. A nightmare.

Sansa is safe, in Winterfell. He made sure for it to happen.

He closes his eyes and shreds of images run through his mind. No matter how hard he tries, he can’t delete them from memory. Deep roots like those of a heart tree are wedged inside him.

After that night, it becomes a recurring dream. See her die, night after night, again and again.

Despite his attempts, every time something inside him seems to break and the craving for home becomes agonizing.

*

“They had to be full of water and instead were empty! How is that possible?”

Of all those present, no one speaks. Tyrion stirs by the queen’s side and Varys remains inscrutable. Davos exchanges a look with Gendry and takes a step forward.

“With all due respect, my lord, Gendry and I were in charge of filling them,” he says. “We can both confirm that they were full when we delivered them to Gray Worm.”

Jon closes his eyes. His hands are locked around the table on which the map of King’s Landing is deployed. His knuckles turn white. When he stares at Gray Worm, he in his usual position, next to Daenerys, with his arms crossed behind his back.

“You ordered them to be emptied,” he accuses him, but his voice sounds more tired than really angry. “Why?”

Gray Worm doesn’t so much as look at him. When he speaks, he turns and looks at the queen, as if the presence and opinion of others are of no relevance to him. “That woman is like the Masters and we will treat her the same way.”

Daenerys doesn’t respond, but her face shows the same hardness that she hasn’t lost since Missandei’s death. She puts her hand on his elbow.

Jon thinks about Mance Rayder. Burnt alive is something he wouldn’t wish to anyone, not even to his worst enemy.

The plan was to burn a small portion of the Flea Bottom, a displaced area and according to reliable sources now uninhabited, and at the same time to launch with catapults barrels of water to extinguish the flames. A play to show the devastating power of a dragon, the threat behind the warning, and have mercy, give a clear message that they are not the true enemy, but that they could become one.

To do something, quieting the desire for bloodbath of the Unsellied.

“What about the women and children who could have died?”

Gray Worm doesn’t blink. “There are always casualties in war.” Everyone knows that he is referring to Missandei.

Out of the corner of his eye he sees Tyrion flinch under Daenerys’ glare.

“You knew it?” He brutally asks her.

Daenerys’s eyes catalyses on him, losing some of her coolness. She hesitates, as if evaluating the options. “No,” she says.

Jon nods, trying to mask the relief he is feeling.

“So it’s insubordination,” he says gravely. From the way she is staring at him, Jon senses that she has already figured out what this means.

“I respected you as commander, but what you did today was unforgivable. We can’t fight a war if we don’t trust each other.”

When they are alone, Daenerys’ fury is incandescent. “What do you think you’re doing?” There is a ferocity in her eyes, the look of a bear mother to which were killed all her cubs, one after the other. “Gray Worm is my commander, a trusted man of the queen.”

“He disobeyed an order! What example would we give to the other commanders if he remains unpunished?”

“I will not punish him just because he sought justice.”

“That wasn’t justice! It was revenge! If we start acting this way, what makes us better than Cersei Lannister?”

He knows he has convinced her when he sees her shrink under the weight of that umpteenth loss.

He would like to comfort her, but as a coward he turns his back and leaves.
